results.title: The Lead dress
results.brief_description: A beautiful, gothic film about a mother so desperate to keep her daughter at home that she sews her a lead dress which impedes her movement. Shot in black and white without dialogue, the film uses a form of pixillation which, when combined with slow-motion performance, gives the effect of its characters moving in a slow and jerky fashion while cars and people in the background flash past at high speed.

results.title: The Law of the sea
results.creator_credit: Edward Magruder Jones, Gilbert Lauzun and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Stresses the need for international cooperation in developing a universally acceptable law of the sea, so that resource-use conflicts between nations such as the Icelandic “cod war” will not occur in the future. Shows the steps which have already been taken in this direction by countries bordering the North Sea. Suitabel for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Laundry
results.creator_credit: Alex Chomicz, Lesley Dyer and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A woman’s trip to the laundromat takes a frightening turn when she encounters a man washing his blood stained clothes. Is he someone to fear? A comedic short film about first impressions and the persuasive power of appearance.

results.title: The Late Show: The Olden days
results.creator_credit: Mark Gibson, ABC-TV (Australia) and D Generation
results.brief_description: In the hands of the D-Generation the original ABC series of ‘Rush’ becomes a steamy tale of hope, betrayal and false moustaches set against the rarely-convincing backdrop of the Victorian ‘mudfields’. Also features a featurette at the end of “Olden Days” which is a tribute to that great Australian auteur Warren Perso (starring Tony Martin and Judith Lucy).

results.title: The Late Show presents: 'The devil at your heels'
results.creator_credit: Adam Symansky, Bill Brand, Robert Fortier, BBC and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This documentary on Canadian stuntman Ken Carter and his obsession with jumping a car over the St Lawrence Seaway - a distance of 1 mile - is presented by Rob Sitch, Santo Cilauro and Aaron Beaucaire, “Late Show” stalwarts and keen amateur stuntmen. Originally shot by reporters form the National Film Board of Canada, the film spans the five years it took to achieve this absurd feat. At 16 Ken Carter joined Joey Chitwood’s “Congress of Canadian Daredevils”. At 17, he was with “The International Hell Drivers”. Twenty years and fifty broken bones later, he decides his one last stunt will be to jump a rocket car from Canada to the USA over the St Lawrence Seaway.

results.title: The Late Show : Bargearse
results.creator_credit: Mark Gibson, ABC-TV (Australia), Crawfords and D-Generation
results.brief_description: By re-voicing the classic 1976 Crawford’s police drama ‘Bluey’, the D-Generation have created an entirely new story which is at once a subtle rumination on the nature of existence, and a thinly-veiled excuse for some really good fart jokes. It should be pointed out that this is not for the faint-hearted or those who may have just eaten.

results.title: The Last whalers
results.creator_credit: Julien Bryan, William Neufeld and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: A study of simple European life that focuses on a group of whalers and on the customs and traditions of the Pico Island villages. Filmed on Pico Island, The Azores (Portugal).

results.title: The Last warriors
results.creator_credit: Ben Ulm, Michael Willesee Jnr and Transmedia Productions
results.brief_description: Television documentary series in five episodes presented and narrated by Mike Willesee looking at the traditional lifestyles and rituals of various African tribes. Ep. 1 focuses on the Hamar and Karo tribes. Ep. 2 follows the Wodaabe and Tureg people, nomadic tribes of the Sahara Desert. In Ep. 3 men from the Mursi tribe prepare for a traditional fighting ritual. Ep. 4 looks at a traditional tribal marriage. Dinka men prepare for an eating contest in Ep. 5. Ep. 6 is a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the series.

results.title: The Last to go
results.creator_credit: John Erman, Freyda Rothstein and Interscope Productions
results.brief_description: This sensitive portrayal of a family relationship traces the path of a seemingly “perfect couple” whose dreams for living happily ever after are painfully shattered. The film begins with Daniel and Mary Ellen moving into their new home. Everything appears to be normal, as Daniel works at furthering his practice as a brain surgeon and his wife devotes herself to their three children. As the film progresses the cracks begin to show, the children grow up and move away, and husband and wife become strangers. As the alienation increases they drift to other people and Daniel begins an affair with one of his nurses while Mary Ellen fantasises about the family gardener. With their marriage well and truly over, Mary Ellen clings to the security of her once happy home, chaining herself to painful memories. Finally, she realises that to move on with her life she must leave the house that once contained the happiness of her marriage. Cast includes Tyne Daly, Terry O’Quinn and Annabeth Gish.

results.title: The Last tall forest
results.brief_description: Presents Tasmania’s remote mountain highland wilderness, the world of high peaks and glacier lakes. In the valleys of Tasmania’s tall forests are the tallest eucalypts of the planet. Scientists have found that plants have existed for 35 million years, but many, such as these tall trees are now threatened by man. Australian animals, such as platypus, wombats, and possums are also shown.
